facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 841 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 841 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated October 12, 1961 of Bombay High Court in Misc. Application No. 379 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 12, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Misc. Application No. 379 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

facts.text: Expenditure-tax Act 29 of 1957 received assent of President on September 17, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Expenditure-tax Act 29 of 1957 which received the assent of the President on September 17, 1957,

facts.text: Expenditure-tax Act brought into force on April 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: was brought into force on April 1, 1958. The Act provides for levy of tax on expenditure

facts.text: His Highness Mahendrasinghji, Ruler of Morvi, died on August 17, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: His Highness Mahendrasinghji, Ruler of Morvi died on August 17, 1957, having made a will

facts.text: Mahendrasinghji made a will appointing respondents as executors of his estate.

anchor.surface_text: having made a will appointing the respondents to this appeal as executors of his estate.

facts.text: Expenditure-tax Officer issued notice under S. 13(2) of the Expenditure-tax Act requiring respondents to furnish return of expenditure by Mahendrasinghji from April 1, 1957 to August 17, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Expenditure-tax Officer issued a notice under S. 13(2) of the Expenditure-tax Act, 1947, requiring the respondents to furnish a return of the expenditure incurred by Mahendrasinghji for the period between April 1, 1957 to August 17, 1957.

facts.text: Respondents submitted that the Act did not apply to Mahendrasinghji because he died before the Act came into force and executors not liable to submit return.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents submitted that the Act did not apply to Mahendrasinghji because he had died before the date on which the Act came into force, and on that account the respondents as executors of his will were not liable to submit the return demanded.

facts.text: Expenditure-tax Officer rejected contention by letter dated November 19, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated November 19, 1959, the Expenditure-tax Officer rejected the contention raised by the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents filed petition in Bombay High Court under Art. 226 to quash proceedings and restrain officer.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then filed a petition in the High Court of Bombay under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying that the proceedings started by the Expenditure-tax Officer for assessing and levying tax on the expenditure incurred by the late Mahendrasinghji during the previous year be quashed and that the Officer be restrained by an injunction from taking further steps or proceedings under the Act.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held charge under Act was on individual incurring expenditure, not estate, and no tax if unit not in existence on April 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the charge under the Act in respect of expenditure incurred in the relevant previous year to the assessment year 1958-59 was not on the estate of any individual or any Hindu undivided family it was on the individual or the Hindu undivided family incurring the expenditure, and as it was imposed for the first time on April 1, 1958, unless the unit of assessment was in existence on the date when the Act came into force, no tax could be levied.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal preferred against High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred.

facts.text: In Ellis Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay High Court held that if person dies after notice under s.22(2) but before return, assessment cannot continue against legal representative.

anchor.surface_text: In Ellis Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax, the Bombay High Court held that where a person dies after the issue of a notice under s. 22(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, to make a return of his income, but before he makes a return, assessment proceedings commenced against him under the Income-tax Act cannot be continued and his legal representative will not be liable to pay tax which such person may, if he had not died, have been assessed to pay.

facts.text: Section 24B added to Income-tax Act 1922 by Amendment Act 18 of 1933 effective September 11, 1933.

anchor.surface_text: Section 24B was added in the Income-tax Act, 1922, by the Income-tax (Second Amendment) Act 18 of 1933 with effect from September 11, 1933,

facts.text: In D.N. Mehta case, Avabai died on May 6, 1932 after notice under s.22(2), Bombay HC held estate not liable under s.24B inserted later.

anchor.surface_text: In D. N. Mehta's case one Avabai died on May 6, 1932 after she was served with a notice requiring her to make a return of her income under s. 22(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. Section 24B was thereafter inserted in the Income-tax Act on September 11, 1933.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that s.18 of Expenditure-tax Act applies to persons dying before Act came into force, estate liable.

anchor.surface_text: The expression 'Where a person dies' standing by itself in s. 18 does not suggest that thereby it was intended to refer only to death of the person liable after the Act was brought into force and read with the remaining clauses in the context of sub-ss. (2) & (3) it is clear that the Parliament intended to attract the entire charge to tax and machinery prescribed by ss. 13-15 so as to render the estate of a person dying before the Act liable to satisfy the tax or other liability which would have been assessed or imposed upon him if he had not died.

facts.text: Parliament adopted scheme of s.24B Income-tax Act in enacting s.18 Expenditure-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The operative terms of sub-s. (1) of s. 18 are identical with the terms of s. 24B(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Respondents contended s.18 only for deaths after Act brought into force, relying on D.N. Mehta.

anchor.surface_text: But counsel for the respondent said that s. 18 of the Expenditure-tax Act does not bring within the net of taxation cases of persons who died before the Act was brought into force it only sets up machinery for enforcing liability against the estate of a person dying after the Act is brought into force. Counsel placed strong reliance upon Income-tax Commissioner, Bombay v. D. N. Mehta decided by the Bombay High Court,

facts.text: Supreme Court disagreed with High Court and respondent's contention that estate not liable if death before Act force.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable therefore to agree with the High Court that by enacting s. 18 of the Act the Parliament has not rendered the estate of a person liable to expenditure-tax, if such person had died before the date on which the Act was brought into force.

under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying that the proceedings started by the Expenditure-tax Officer for assessing and levying tax on the expenditure incurred by the late Mahendrasinghji during the previous year be quashed and that the Officer be restrained by an injunction from taking further steps or proceedings under the Act.
under S. 13 2  of the Expenditure-tax Act, 1947, requiring the respondents to furnish a return of the expenditure incurred by Mahendrasinghji for the period between April 1, 1957 to August 17, 1957.

Section 2 c  of the Expenditure-tax Act 29 of 1957 defines an assessee as meaning an individual or a Hindu undivided family by whom expenditure-tax or any other sum of money is payable under the Act, and includes every individual or Hindu undivided family against whom any proceeding under the Act has been taken for the assessment of his expenditure.

The relevant part of s. 3 which is the charging section provides. Subject to the other provisions contained in this Act, there shall be charged for every financial year commencing on and from the first day of April, 1958, a tax  hereinafter referred to as expenditure-tax  at the rate or rates specified in the Schedule in respect of the expenditure incurred by any individual or Hindu undivided family in the previous year

concepts.interpretation: Charging section for expenditure-tax on individuals or HUF in previous year

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: relevant previous year to the assessment year 1958-59 was number on the estate of any individual or any Hindu undivided family it was on the individu

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 deals with returns of expenditure for the purpose of assessment of tax. It provides Every person whose expenditure for the previous6s year was of such an amount as to render him liable to expenditure-tax under this Act shall, before the thirtieth day of June of the corresponding assessment year, furnish to the Expenditure-tax Officer a return in the prescribed form and verified in the prescribed manner setting forth his expenditure for the previous year.

concepts.interpretation: Requires furnishing of returns by persons liable to tax

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: his expenditure. Assessment year under the Act means the year for which tax is chargeable under s. 3, and previous year is defined in relation to any

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 enables a return to be made, if it is not furnished within the time allowed, or to be modified, at any time before the assessment is made.

Section 15 confers power upon the Expenditure-tax Officer to assess tax. If the Officer is satisfied without requiring the presence of the assessee or production by him of any evidence that a return made under s. 13 or s. 14 is correct and complete, he must assess the taxable expenditure of the assessee and determine the amount payable by him as expenditure-tax.

concepts.interpretation: Assessment procedure including best judgment assessment

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 provides Where a person dies, his executor, administrator or other legal representative shall be liable to pay out of the estate of the deceased person to the extent to which the estate is capable of meeting the charge, the expenditure-tax assessed as payable by such person, or any sum which would have been payable by him under this Act if he had not died.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to persons dying before the Act came into force; renders estate liable for tax that would have been payable if deceased had survived; machinery under ss.13-15 applies to legal representatives

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: of the declared liability under sub-s.  1  and the provisions of sub-s.  3  of s. 18, which make sections 13, 14 and 15 of the Expenditure-tax Act app

concepts.unlisted_description: Liability of legal representatives upon death

anchor.surface_text: The operative terms of sub-s. (1) of s. 18 are identical with the terms of s. 24B(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. Section 24B was added in the Income-tax Act, 1922, by the Income-tax (Second Amendment) Act 18 of 1933 with effect from September 11, 1933,

concepts.interpretation: Parliament adopted its scheme for machinery to assess tax on estate of deceased; identical operative terms to Expenditure-tax Act s.18(1)

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: d was to make a return under s. 13 1 , and that the Tax Officer is invested with power to call for return from the legal representative of a deceased

concepts.interpretation: Charges tax on persons alive at start of financial year; liability inchoate if death before assessment (per Bombay HC)

anchor.surface_text: The principle which must always be applied in construing a taxing Act is that the Government must show that the tax sought be recovered has been imposed in language which admits of no reasonable doubt. The opening words of each sub-section to Section 24-B Where a person dies, though the use of the present tense is not altogether appropriate on any reading of the Act, seem to me more appropriate to future than to past deaths.

concepts.interpretation: Respondent relies on it to argue no retrospective liability; court rejects, finding clear intention from context

concepts.unlisted_description: Tax liability must be shown in clear language without reasonable doubt; no retrospectivity unless expressly stated

issues.text: Whether the charge under the Act is on the individual or Hindu undivided family incurring the expenditure such that unless the unit of assessment was in existence on the date when the Act came into force no tax could be levied on the estate of a deceased person

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the charge under the Act in respect of expenditure incurred in the relevant previous year to the assessment year 1958-59 was not on the estate of any individual or any Hindu undivided family it was on the individual or the Hindu undivided family incurring the expenditure, and as it was imposed for the first time on April 1, 1958, unless the unit of assessment was in existence on the date when the Act came into force, no tax could be levied.

issues.text: Whether Parliament has failed to set up effective machinery for assessing tax against the estate of a person who died during the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1958-59 so as to render his estate liable under the Act

anchor.surface_text: Power of the Parliament to enact legislation for assessing tax against the representatives of a person who died before the date on which the Act was brought into force and for collecting it from his estate is not challenged. It is however submitted that the Parliament has failed to set up effective machinery for assessing tax against the estate of a person who died during the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1958-59 so as to render his estate liable under the Act.

issues.text: Whether there is anything in the expression 'Where a person dies' or in the context which suggests that it was intended to restrict the operation of sub-s. (1) of s. 18 to cases of persons dying after the Act was brought into force

Whether Parliament, having adopted the phraseology of s. 24B(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1922 with the judicial interpretation in D. N. Mehta's case excluding past deaths, intended the same for s. 18(1) of the Expenditure-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent maintained that as with this judicial interpretation of s. 24B before it, the Parliament adopted the same phraseology and scheme in enacting s. 18(1) of the Expenditure-tax Act, Parliament must be deemed to have intended to enact the rule laid by the Bombay High Court in its application to the Expenditure-tax Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Expression 'Where a person dies' does not suggest only post-Act deaths; read with sub-ss(2)(3) context shows intent to attract ss13-15 machinery for pre-Act deaths

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent maintained that as with this judicial interpretation of s. 24B before it, the Parliament adopted the same phraseology and scheme in enacting s. 18(1) of the Expenditure-tax Act, Parliament must be deemed to have intended to enact the rule laid by the Bombay High Court in its application to the Expenditure-tax Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of the declared liability under sub-s.  1  and the provisions of sub-s.  3  of s. 18, which make sections 13, 14 and 15 of the Expenditure-tax Act app

arguments.court_reasoning: Despite identical terms, context of s.18 sub-ss(2)(3) shows clear intention unlike narrow view in D.N. Mehta; strict construction satisfied by context

arguments.claim: Strict construction of taxing statutes requires clear language for retrospectivity; 'Where a person dies' more apt for future deaths; could have said 'dies whether before or after'

anchor.surface_text: The principle which must always be applied in construing a taxing Act is that the Government must show that the tax sought be recovered has been imposed in language which admits of no reasonable doubt. The opening words of each sub-section to Section 24-B Where a person dies, though the use of the present tense is not altogether appropriate on any reading of the Act, seem to me more appropriate to future than to past deaths.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to force. The argument of inconvenience has numbersubstance. A person who has rendered himself liable to pay tax on the expenditure incurred by him in

arguments.court_reasoning: Context of s.18(1) with sub-ss(2)(3) expresses intention clearly to render pre-Act death estates liable; strict construction met

arguments.claim: Nothing in expression 'Where a person dies' or context restricts s.18(1) to deaths after Act brought into force
Scheme of s.18 declares liability on estate by sub-s(1), invests ETO with ss13-15 powers vs legal reps by sub-ss(2)(3); applies to pre-Act deaths

anchor.surface_text: In terms, sub-s. (1) of S. 18, imposes liability upon the legal representatives of a person who dies, to pay out of his estate, expenditure-tax assessed as payable by such person, or any sum which would have been payable by him if he had not died. There is nothing in the expression Where a person dies or in the context in which it occurs which suggests that it was intended thereby to restrict the operation of the sub-section to cases of persons dying after the Act was brought into force.

arguments.claim: Parliament adopted scheme of s.24B Income-tax Act (inserted to remedy lacuna for deceased assessees) in enacting s.18 Expenditure-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The operative terms of sub-s. (1) of s. 18 are identical with the terms of s. 24B(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. Section 24B was added in the Income-tax Act, 1922, by the Income-tax (Second Amendment) Act 18 of 1933 with effect from September 11, 1933, to remedy a lacuna which was pointed out by the Bombay High Court in the machinery provisions of the Income-tax Act insofar as they related to assessment of tax against the estate of a person who died before assessment was completed.

arguments.claim: s.18 expression 'Where a person dies' read with context of sub-ss(2)(3) shows clear intent to apply charge and ss13-15 machinery to estates of pre-Act deaths

anchor.surface_text: The expression 'Where a person dies' standing by itself in s. 18 does not suggest that thereby it was intended to refer only to death of the person liable after the Act was brought into force and read with the remaining clauses in the context of sub-ss. (2) & (3) it is clear that the Parliament intended to attract the entire charge to tax and machinery prescribed by ss. 13-15 so as to render the estate of a person dying before the Act liable to satisfy the tax or other liability which would have been assessed or imposed upon him if he had not died.

arguments.claim: Argument of inconvenience or hardship from estate distribution has no substance; does not defeat statutory liability
Parliament by s.18 rendered estate of person liable to expenditure-tax even if died before Act brought into force

anchor.surface_text: We are unable therefore to agree with the High Court that by enacting s. 18 of the Act the Parliament has not rendered the estate of a person liable to expenditure-tax, if such person had died before the date on which the Act was brought into force.

holdings.text: By enacting s. 18 of the Expenditure-tax Act, Parliament has rendered the estate of a person liable to expenditure-tax even if such person had died before the date on which the Act was brought into force.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18(1) imposes liability on estate for tax payable if deceased alive; sub-ss.(2)&(3) apply ss.13-15 machinery to legal representatives; rejects High Court view limiting to living units.

holdings.text: There is nothing in the expression 'Where a person dies' or in the context which suggests that it was intended to restrict the operation of sub-s.(1) of s.18 to cases of persons dying after the Act was brought into force.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading in harmonious context with sub-ss.(2)&(3) shows broad application; no restriction to post-enactment deaths.

holdings.text: The scheme of s.18 declares liability on the estate by sub-s.(1) and invests the Expenditure-tax Officer with powers under ss.13,14,15 against legal representatives by sub-ss.(2)&(3), rendering estate liable even for pre-Act deaths.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of s. 18 is that by sub-s. (1) liability of the estate of a person who dies, to satisfy the tax liability if his expenditure in the previous year exceeds the amount which renders him liable to the expenditure-tax, is declared, and by sub-ss. (2) & (3) the Expenditure-tax Officer is invested with power to require a return to be made by the legal representative of a deceased person whose estate is liable to pay the tax, or to deal with a return already made, and to determine after assessment the tax payable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit machinery provisions apply ss.13-15 to legal reps as if deceased alive; effective for assessment and collection from estate.

holdings.text: Parliament did not intend s.18 to follow the narrow interpretation in D.N. Mehta's case excluding estates of persons dying before the amending Act; context shows clear intention for pre-Act deaths.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Despite identical phraseology to s.24B, context of sub-ss.(2)&(3) distinguishes; Parliament remedied similar lacuna proactively.

holdings.text: The argument of inconvenience or hardship from estate distribution does not defeat the statutory liability under the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory liability prevails over post-expenditure distribution; no defense against levy.

precedents.citation: Ellis Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1

anchor.surface_text: Ellis Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 , the Bombay High Court held that where a person dies after the issue of a notice under s. 22 2 of the Income-tax Act, 1922, to make a return of his income, but before he makes a return, assessment proceedings commenced against him under the Income-tax Act cannot be continued and his legal representative will number be liable to pay tax which such person may, if he had number died, have been assessed to pay. In the view of the High Court the definition of assessee applies only to a living person, the expression used by the Legislature being a person by whom income-tax is payable and number a person by whom or whose estate income-tax is payable.

precedents.case_name: Ellis Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: where a person dies after the issue of a notice under s. 22(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, to make a return of his income, but before he makes a return, assessment proceedings commenced against him under the Income-tax Act cannot be continued and his legal representative will not be liable to pay tax which such person may, if he had not died, have been assessed to pay; definition of assessee applies only to a living person
precedents.cited_holding: assessment proceedings cannot be continued and his legal representative will number be liable to pay tax

precedents.citation: income-tax Commissioner, Bombay v. D. N. Mehta 2

anchor.surface_text: income-tax Commissioner, Bombay v. D. N. Mehta 2 decided by the Bombay High Court, and submitted that Parliament having adopted the same phraseology as was used in I s. 24B 1 of the Income-tax Act, it may be inferred that it was intended to give legislative recognition to the interpretation of 1 5 I.T.C. 100 I.L.R. 55 Bom. 312. 2 3 I.T.R. 147 s.24 insofar as it is applicable to the Expenditure-tax Act. In D. N. Mehtas case 1 one Avabai died on May 6, 1932 after she was served with a numberice requiring her to make a return of her income under s. 22 2 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

precedents.case_name: Income-tax Commissioner, Bombay v. D. N. Mehta
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 24B(1) of the Income-tax Act does not apply to deaths occurring before the amendment introducing s. 24B; the phrase 'Where a person dies' refers to future deaths, not past deaths before the Act
precedents.cited_holding: the Amendment Act does for the first time impose an enforceable liability; opening words 'Where a person dies' more appropriate to future than to past deaths; if retrospective, would have said 'dies whether before or after the passing of this Act'

anchor.surface_text: In D. N. Mehtas case 1 one Avabai died on May 6, 1932 after she was served with a numberice requiring her to make a return of her income under s. 22 2 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. Section 24B was thereafter inserted in the Income-tax Act on September 11, 1933. In proceedings for assessment of income-tax against her legal representatives it was companytended that Avabai had died before the date on which the amendment was made, her estate was number liable to be taxed under the machinery incorporated in the Act in S. 24B. This companytention found favour with the Bombay High Court in D. N. Mehtas case 1 . Beaumont, C.J., delivering the judgment of the Court observed that S. 3 of the Income-tax Act charges the tax upon every one companying within the purview of the Act who was alive at the beginning of the financial year, but in the case of a person dying before assessment, that liability was inchoate only, and crystallized into an enforceable liability for the first time on the passing of the Amendment Act.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. D. N. Mehta
precedents.cited_proposition: estate not liable under s. 24B if death before amendment; liability inchoate until amendment; phraseology indicates no retrospective effect
precedents.cited_holding: If the Legislature had intended the Act to have a retrospective effect, it would have been very easy to have said, dies whether before or after the passing of this Act.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention found favour with the Bombay High Court in D. N. Mehtas case 1 . Beaumont, C.J., delivering the judgment of the Court observed that S. 3 of the Income-tax Act charges the tax upon every one companying within the purview of the Act who was alive at the beginning of the financial year, but in the case of a person dying before assessment, that liability was inchoate only, and crystallized into an enforceable liability for the first time on the passing of the Amendment Act. It is therefore number quite accurate to say that the Amendment Act merely deals with machinery it does for the first time impose an enforceable liability. The principle which must always be applied in companystruing a taxing Act is that the Government must show that the tax sought be recovered has been imposed in language which admits of numberreasonable doubt.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. D. N. Mehta
precedents.cited_proposition: liability was inchoate and crystallized only on passing of amendment; amendment imposes enforceable liability first time; present tense in 'Where a person dies' appropriate for future deaths
precedents.cited_holding: the opening words of each sub-section to Section 24-B Where a person dies [...] seem to me more appropriate to future than to past deaths

anchor.surface_text: We are unable therefore to agree with the High Court that by enacting s. 18 of the Act the Parliament has number rendered the estate of a person liable to expenditure-tax, if such person had died before the date on which the Act was brought into force.

outcome.relief_summary: Disagreed with the High Court and held that the Parliament has rendered the estate of a person liable to expenditure-tax under s. 18 even if the person died before the Act was brought into force

edges.explanation: s.13 (requiring furnishing of returns) provides the statutory basis grounded in the holding's description of powers under s.13 invested by s.18(2).

anchor.surface_text: t up effective machinery for assessing tax against the estate of a person who died during the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1958-59 so

edges.explanation: The holding explicitly refers to powers under ss.13,14,15, including Section 14 (c6), as part of the scheme declaring liability on the estate and empowering assessment against legal representatives.
Supreme Court holding on s.18 applicability to pre-Act deaths and estate liability supports the scheme interpretation in h3 regarding s.18 liability and powers under s.13.
SC holding that s.18 makes estates liable supports existence of machinery for assessment against estates, countering claim of parliamentary failure in i2.

The holding explains liability of the estate even if the person died before the relevant date, directly addressing the issue's question on whether the unit of assessment (individual or HUF) must exist on that date for the charge to apply.

anchor.surface_text: t up effective machinery for assessing tax against the estate of a person who died during the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1958-59 so

edges.explanation: The holding counters the claim of failure to set up machinery by explaining the scheme under s.18(1) for estate liability and powers under ss.13,14,15 against legal representatives for assessment on deceased's estate.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of s. 18 is that by sub-s. (1) liability of the estate of a person who dies, to satisfy the tax liability if his expenditure in the previous year exceeds the amount which renders him liable to the expenditure-tax, is declared, and by sub-ss. (2) & (3) the Expenditure-tax Officer is invested with power to require a return to be made by the legal representative of a deceased person whose estate is liable to pay the tax, or to deal with a return already made, and to determine after assessment the tax payable.

We are unable therefore to agree with the High Court that by enacting s. 18 of the Act the Parliament has number rendered the estate of a person liable to expenditure-tax, if such person had died before the date on which the Act was brought into force.
